href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/announcement-ecouterre-is-rejoining-the-mother-ship/\"><img src=\"\" data-original=\"//www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home-537x192.jpg\" alt=\"Ecouterre rejoining inhabitat, Ecouterre merging with Inhabitat.com\" width=\"537\" height=\"192\" class=\"alignnone size-large lzy wp-image-118344\" srcset=\"//www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home-537x192.jpg 537w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home-300x107.jpg 300w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home-768x275.jpg 768w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home-900x322.jpg 900w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home-728x260.jpg 728w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Back-Home.jpg 948w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 537px) 100vw, 537px\"></a></p>\n<p>Dear Ecouterre readers,</p>\n<p>We want to thank you for sharing this journey with us for the past eight years.  Ecouterre.com broke ground in 2009 as the world’s first website dedicated to ethical and environmentally sustainable fashion.  We helped to start the conversation about <a href=\"http://ecouterre.com\">“eco fashion”</a> when that term was fairly unknown, and left most in the fashion industry and general public scratching their heads.  Now <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/eco-celebs\">major celebrities endorse eco-fashion</a>, major retailers like <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/hm\">H&amp;M</a> and <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/inditex\">Inditex</a> integrate environmental practices into their production, and <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/kering\">luxury fashion houses</a> talk about <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/stella-mccartney-releases-first-environmental-profit-loss-account/\">“natural capital accounting.”</a> We are thrilled to see how far the conversation has come, and we know that the discussion around how to manufacture apparel responsibly and ethically needs to continue, as there is much work still to be done.</p>\n<p>We would like to share with you today the fact that the Ecouterre website will be folding back into our original mothership, <a href=\"http://www.inhabitat.com\">Inhabitat.com.</a> When we spun Ecouterre off from design website Inhabitat.com in 2009, it was because we felt there needed to be a separate space for conversation dedicated to eco-fashion, apart from <a href=\"http://www.inhabitat.com\">Inhabitat</a>, which was covering a wide range of human design, including architecture, urban design, product design, and industrial design. </p>\n<p><img src=\"//www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-537x375.jpg\" alt=\"Ecouterre rejoining inhabitat, Ecouterre merging with Inhabitat.com\" width=\"537\" height=\"375\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-118343\" srcset=\"//www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-537x375.jpg 537w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-300x209.jpg 300w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-768x536.jpg 768w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-900x628.jpg 900w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-728x508.jpg 728w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home.jpg 919w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 537px) 100vw, 537px\"></p>\n<p>While this separate conversation for fashion still feels so necessary, the rapidly changing dynamics of internet publishing has fundamentally altered Ecouterre’s audience, our revenue and the long-term viability of our business operations as an independent website.  Because of this, we need to fold Ecouterre back into <a href=\"http://www.inhabitat.com\">Inhabitat.com.</a>, in order to sustain the content and mission of our work.</p>\n<p>Sometime this spring (date still TBD), we will migrate the Ecouterre content over to Inhabitat.com, under the “Ecouterre” category. Ecouterre will still maintain its brand and logo over at Inhabitat, but the content will all now be hosted on Inhabitat.com.  All of the old Ecouterre.com urls will forward to their new locations on Inhabitat.com.  The webpages within Inhabitat.com will look like this:</p>\n<p><img src=\"//www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-537x375.jpg\" alt=\"Ecouterre rejoining inhabitat, Ecouterre merging with Inhabitat.com\" width=\"537\" height=\"375\" class=\"alignnone size-large wp-image-118343\" srcset=\"//www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-537x375.jpg 537w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-300x209.jpg 300w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-768x536.jpg 768w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-900x628.jpg 900w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home-728x508.jpg 728w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Ecouterre-Going-Home.jpg 919w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 537px) 100vw, 537px\"></p>\n<p>We want to thank our dedicated readers for taking this journey with us, and we hope you will join us over on Inhabitat.com for our next chapter in fighting the good fight for sustainable design.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\t\t\t\t<!-- google_ad_section_end -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"post-share\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- the +1 button  -->\n<div id=\"___plusone_0\" style=\"text-indent: 0px; being bold and brave; and now we’ve proved this true again! We’re now calling out for the world’s best sustainable fashion designers to compete in the just-opened 2017 <a href=\"http:// www.ecochicdesignaward.com/\">EcoChic Design Award</a> cycle. And—drumroll please±we’ve lifted the lid on who can apply so that designers with less than three years’ industry experience living in Asia, Europe and, for the first time, the United States can enter via <a href=\"http://www.ecochicdesignaward.com\">www.ecochicdesignaward.com</a> until the deadline on April 3. Following a design rollercoaster, the 10 finalists will bring the convictions and collections to Hong Kong in September 2017 for the catwalk finale show that will change their life; with cameras filming every step of the way for Frontline Fashion Season 2. Images</a></small></p>\n<p>What was inside the blue Tiffany box that Melania Trump handed Michelle Obama on Inauguration Day? The world may never know. Less of a mystery is <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/pamela-anderson\">Pamela Anderson’s</a> would-be gift to the current First Lady: a Russian <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/faux-fur\">faux fur</a>. “I’m going to send her one of my Russian eco-fur coats as a gift because I’m designing furs in Russia right now,” the OG <em><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baywatch\">Baywatch</a></em> babe and <a href=\"http://metro.co.uk/2017/01/20/pamela-anderson-is-the-newest-face-of-vivian-westwood-6392261/\">Vivienne Westwood muse</a> told <a href=\"http://thehill.com/blogs/in-the-know/in-the-know/315913-pamela-anderson-plans-to-give-russian-faux-fur-to-melania-trump\">The Hill</a> at a <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/peta/\">People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals</a> soiree in Washington, D.C., last week. A longtime animal-rights advocate with <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/pamela-anderson-launches-two-vegan-shoe-collections\">not one but two</a> vegan shoe collections to her name, Anderson said that while she didn’t know where President Trump stood on the issue, “his wife Melania’s favorite designer is <a href=\"http://www.marcbouwer.com/\">Marc Bouwer</a>, as far as I’ve heard. And he’s a vegan designer.”</p>\n<div class=\"gallery\"><dl class=\"gallery-item\"><dt class=\"gallery-icon3\">\n\t\t\t\t<a its nose for the clothing we produce, according to <a href=\"http://mst.dk/media/129531/natural-capital-account-for-the-danish-apparel-sector_final.pdf\">a study</a> that quantifies, for the first time, the price we exact from the ecosystem for our clothing. Case in point? Factoring in the use of water, fertilizer, and energy along the entire supply chain, a single cotton T-shirt can cost the planet more than 20 Danish kroner, or $3.40, in financial terms. Extrapolated across the industry, clothing consumption in Denmark alone plunders the environment of more than DKK 3 billion ($510 million) every year. This toll is much too high, says Kirsten Brosbøl, head of <a href=\"http://eng.mim.dk/\">Denmark’s Ministry of the Environment</a>, which partnered with the <a href=\"http://www.icgroup.net/brands/\">IC Group</a>, operator of brands like <a href=\"http://tigerofsweden.com/se/\">Tiger of Sweden</a> and <a href=\"http://www.peakperformance.com/se/\">Peak Performance</a>, to commission the report. </p>\n<div class=\"gallery\"><dl class=\"gallery-item\"><dt class=\"gallery-icon3\">\n\t\t\t\t<a class=\"post-content\">\n\t\t\t\t<p><a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/bangladeshs-children-are-working-60-hours-a-week-to-make-our-fast-fashion/\"><img src=\"\" //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/bangladesh-child-labor-1-900x675.jpg 900w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/bangladesh-child-labor-1-728x546.jpg 728w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/bangladesh-child-labor-1.jpg 1580w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 537px) 100vw, 537px\"></a></p>\n<p>It’s time to face the awful truth: Those <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/fast-fashion\">cheap clothes</a> we can’t get enough are probably the handiwork of impoverished children from Bangladesh, some as young as 6. About a third of the children who live in the slums of the capital of Dhaka spend an average of 64 hours a week making clothing for the world’s leading brands and retailers, according to the <a href=\"https://www.odi.org/publications/10654-child-labour-and-education-survey-slum-settlements-dhaka\">Overseas Development Institute</a>. The London-based think tank, which conducted a survey of 2,700 households, found that 32 percent of 10- to 14-year-olds were skipping school so they could work full time at garment factories. Most of them earned less than $2 a day. “Our survey raises serious concerns over the issue of child labor in the supply of garments from factories in Bangladesh to consumers in Europe, the U.S., and elsewhere,” ODI said.</p>\n<div class=\"gallery\"><dl class=\"gallery-item\"><dt class=\"gallery-icon3\">\n\t\t\t\t<a Small wonder, then, that fashion brands—those peddlers of dreams and artificers of cool—might be loathe to embrace something that might make them appear gauche by association. \"Sustainability is a lot of things but it's not seen as very stylish, especially with fashion,\" Giusy Bettoni, CEO of <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/c-l-a-s-s-s-textile-library-is-sustainable-fashions-secret-weapon\">C.L.A.S.S.</a> (Creativity Lifestyle and Sustainable Synergy), an eco-textile consultancy based in Milan, told a rapt assembly at <a href=\"http://www.ecoutere.com/tag/cfda\">Council of Fashion Designers of America</a> in New York City last week. \"When I talk about sustainability, the value decreases by 50 percent.\" We can blame the messaging for this—no self-respecting maison wants to come out smelling like patchouli, after all. \"Communication hasn't succeeded in delivering a clear message around //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/patagonia-fair-trade-1-728x546.jpg 728w, //www.ecouterre.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/patagonia-fair-trade-1.jpg 1580w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 537px) 100vw, 537px\"></a></p>\n<p>More than 40 million people work in the global garment industry, yet their stories rarely make the headlines. We’ll tut-tut about the factory fires, the <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/rana-plaza/\">building collapses</a>, the <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/hundreds-sick-in-mass-fainting-at-hm-factory-in-cambodia/\">fainting epidemics</a>, and the deaths we hear about, of course. But the punishingly long days, the unrelenting labor, and the countless indignities workers endure? They’re a little easier to ignore. “It completely changes the way you think about clothing when you consider the people in the process,” Helena Barbour, senior director of global sportswear at <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/patagonia/\">Patagonia</a>, says in <a href=\"http://www.patagonia.com/blog/2016/10/fair-trade-the-first-step/\"><em>Fair Trade: The First Step</em></a>, a new 13-minute film by the outdoor-apparel brand. “But because there is no visibility when you buy garments, you are just oblivious to it.” </p>\n<div class=\"gallery\"><dl class=\"gallery-item\"><dt href=\"http://www.shutterstock.com/pic-236264134/stock-photo-a-shopper-walking-past-a-store-window.html\">Shutterstock</a></small></p>\n<p>Roomful of clothes but nothing to wear? You’re hardly alone. The average U.K. household owns an average of £4,000 worth of clothes, 30 percent of which languishes unworn, according to the <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/u-k-consumers-own-30-billion-worth-of-clothing-they-never-wear/\">Waste &amp; Resources Action Programme</a>. A third of the clothing we buy every year ends up in the landfill, sometimes after <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/a-third-of-brits-admit-to-discarding-six-or-more-garments-over-the-past-year/\">just one use</a>. And let’s not forget all the shoes we <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/survey-reveals-that-most-women-dont-wear-half-of-the-shoes-they-buy/\">never wear</a>. With mindless consumerism hitting its peak on <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/black-friday/\">Black Friday</a>, it’s time for a new consumer revolution, one characterized less by impulse buys and more by thoughtful purchases. “The fashion industry would have us believe that overconsumption is something to be proud of, marking our success one haul at a time,” <a href=\"//www.ecouterre.com/tag/greenpeace\">Greenpeace</a> says in its latest campaign. “But putting aside barely worn clothing and bringing home bags of new outfits fuels a toxic supply chain and stuffs landfills with impulse buys.”</p>\n<div class=\"gallery\"><dl class=\"gallery-item\"><dt class=\"gallery-icon3\">\n\t\t\t\t<a
